items.q: You’re placed in charge of a failing community project. What do you do first?

a.q: Assess the current system’s weaknesses and begin fixing it.
Share the truth of the situation as widely as possible to prompt urgency.
Reaffirm the original mission and remind people why this mattered.
Protect the group from blame and outside pressure.
Mediate the different voices to understand what’s really going wrong.
Introduce a jarring shift to break stagnation and expose blind spots.
Rebuild trust and connection before addressing logistics.
Suggest stepping away entirely to find a better path elsewhere.
Deliver a passionate call to action to reignite purpose.
Observe quietly and avoid getting entangled unless absolutely necessary.

items.q: You’re given a powerful tool with no instructions. What do you do?

a.q: Deconstruct it to reverse-engineer its function.
Announce its discovery and speculate publicly about its use.
Compare it to traditional models or historical examples.
Safeguard it — its misuse might be dangerous.
Cross-reference it with other tools or ideas you've seen.
Try something unexpected to see how it reacts.
Ask others how it makes them feel and what they imagine it could do.
Use it impulsively — the only way to learn is to act.
Use it to provoke excitement and momentum.
Set it aside — not everything needs to be used.

items.q: A person close to you has started to change in ways you don’t understand. How do you react?

a.q: Try to analyze the changes rationally and quietly.
Speak to them openly — they need to hear how this affects others.
Reference the values or history you’ve shared to reconnect.
Stay close and offer protection, even without understanding.
Try to see their changes as part of a bigger pattern.
Challenge their assumptions to spark honest discussion.
Show up emotionally and support them where they are.
Respect their transformation and let them evolve freely.
Respond with passion — connection is meant to be intense.
Withdraw. People change. You don’t need to follow.

items.q: You’re invited into a high-stakes collaboration with unclear power dynamics. How do you approach it?

a.q: Define clear roles and responsibilities early on.
Ask direct questions to clarify what others may avoid saying.
Honor legacy structures and let them guide your behavior.
Stay alert for signs of harm or unfair treatment and step in if needed.
Study the people involved and find the common thread.
Challenge assumptions subtly to test people’s honesty.
Build trust through one-on-one connections before committing.
Use it as a chance to explore, not control.
Assert yourself boldly — your energy is your leverage.
Remain on the fringe, involved but not invested.

items.q: A group you're in is spiraling into chaos. What's your natural response?

a.q: Quietly restructure everything — clarity will stabilize it.
Speak openly to cut through confusion.
Remind the group of its purpose and original agreements.
Focus on grounding and protecting individuals who are overwhelmed.
Map the chaos — there's a pattern inside it.
Amplify the chaos briefly to show what’s broken.
Soothe tensions and rebuild emotional safety.
Let the group fall — maybe it’s not meant to survive.
Take charge through sheer presence and intensity.
Detach. Chaos isn’t your responsibility.

items.q: You discover a truth that could destabilize something important. What do you do?

a.q: Weigh the consequences before acting.
Share it — people deserve to know, even if it shakes things.
Preserve the system; not all truths need telling.
Reveal it only if someone’s safety depends on it.
Frame the truth carefully to integrate it without collapse.
Leak it in a way that forces others to confront it.
Tell those affected directly and support them through it.
Take the truth and walk — you don’t owe anyone a fight.
Turn it into a rallying cry for change.
Keep it to yourself. Let the truth be your own silence.
